prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: AGC181559
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Single Band 3 pointing. The goal is to obtain a CO(1-0) spectrum of the target

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity
In order to map the CO distribution in our sources we need to detect CO at, at least, ~10 sigma level in each beam. Our objects have a typical SFR surface density >0.02 Msun yr^-1 kpc^-2 which, for the Kennicut-Schmidt law, corresponds to a H2 column density of ~40 Msun pc^-2
For a resolution of 1.55 arcsec (~6kpc at z~0.2), the above column density limit corresponds to a 10 sigma mass limit of ~1.7x10^9 Msun. Assuming a CO-to-H2 conversion factor of 3.2 Msun pc^-2 (K km s^-1 pc^2)^-1 (typical of metal-rich galaxies), this corresponds to a CO(1-0) luminosity L_CO = 0.52 x 10^8 = 3.25 x 10^7 x S_CO x nu_obs^-2 x D_L^2 x (1+z)^-3 [K km s^-1 pc^2] (where nu_obs is the observed frequency of the CO line, D_L is the luminosity distance, and z the redshift of the source).
Our 10 sigma integrated flux limit is therefore 0.27 Jy km s^-1. Assuming that the signal will be spread over 100 km s^-1, this correspond to a rms of ~ 0.27 mJy beam^-1 for a 100 km s^-1 velocity resolution.
According to the ALMA Observing Tool, this rms can be achieved with ~35 min on source.
Imaging. This project does not have strong imaging requirements. Our main goal is to recover the CO(1-0) flux of our galaxies, determine the extent of the CO emission, the gas kinematics in each beam. A spatial resolution of ~1.55 arcsec corresponds to 6kpc, allowing us to resolve the CO emission (expected to extend up to 18") without the need of ACA.
Correlator set-up The observations proposed here are straightforward. The CO(1-0) line will be observed with Baseband-1 at a velocity resolution of ~1.5 km s^-1. The tree remaining base-bands will be used for continuum observations. Each Baseband will cover 2GHz bandwidth and will be centered at rest-frame frequency of 115, 128.7 and 131 GHz, respectively.
Time constraints. None.
User defined calibration. None

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to use ALMA to measure the molecular hydrogen content and kinematics of 5 unusually HI-rich galaxies at z~0.2. These are drawn from a sample that includes not only the highest redshift detections of HI emission to date, but also the most HI massive disk galaxies known in the local Universe, with HI-to-stellar mass ratios up to 190%. These rare systems present striking similarities to the z>1 gas-rich disks. Although we have tantalizing evidence that our galaxies might host exceptionally large reservoirs of molecular hydrogen, only resolved ALMA observations will establish our sample as the only local analogue to the z>1 gas-rich disks with HI (and H2) measurements --- suggesting that large HI reservoirs might be present also in the z>1 systems, usually assumed to be HI-poor. Indeed, the existence of rare, local galaxies similar to the z>1 gas-rich disks but with huge reservoirs of hydrogen in both atomic and molecular phases would bring us to question the widely accepted notion that hydrogen in the z>1 star-forming disks is effectively only molecular, forcing us to rethink our current picture of the balance between HI, H2 and star formation as a function of redshift.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Centre of Astrophysics and Supercomputing, Swinburne University of Technology

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Centre of Astrophysics and Supercomputing, Swinburne University of Technology
